summary.p: [1] Now would be the right opportunity to buy beautiful, colorful, and good wool, because by Pentecost [May 29], it is to be taken [to the fair] to Zurzach and then to Strasbourg. If Bullinger is interested, he should communicate the desired colors.

[2] In Frankfurt, there were disturbances due to the arrest of six citizens who allegedly planned an abduction of Maximilian von Egmont, the Count of Buren, with a Hessian nobleman [Hans Ecker von Gelnhausen]. Some believe that the news is fabricated.

[3] Elector Johann Friedrich of Saxony is supported by the Bohemians and Poles. He is said to have captured Maximilian, the son of King Ferdinand, and shot Duke Maurice of Saxony. Allegedly, Ferdinand, surrounded in a small town, is crying for help. Landgrave Philip of Hesse is said to be preparing strongly to free Bremen, which is besieged by Martin von Rossem and his Dutch army. However, he has no artillery. It is confirmed that the Bohemians have defected from the king.
[4] In Strasbourg, an uprising is feared due to the disgraceful submission. Oh, these greedy merchants! Regards.

div.p: Greetings in the Lord. If you want to buy beautiful, colorful, and exquisite wool, you can send me the colors you desire. You will never find them more beautiful than now. Therefore, be warned in time. By Pentecost, they will be taken to Zurzach and Strasbourg.

News, which perhaps you know better than I do: There has been an uprising in Frankfurt, with six citizens arrested. It is said that they wanted to abduct Maximilian von Egmont, the Count of Buren, with a Hessian nobleman. Some believe it is merely a fabrication by them.

The Elector of Saxony, Johann Friedrich, has much support from the Bohemians and Poles; he is said to have captured Maximilian, the son of Ferdinand, and shot Duke Maurice. Ferdinand is crying for help, surrounded in a small town. It is said that the Landgrave is preparing strongly to relieve Bremen, which is besieged by Martin von Rossem, who has a Dutch army. However, he is said to have no artillery with him. It is certain that the Bohemians have defected from Ferdinand.
In Strasbourg, they fear an uprising due to the disgraceful submission. Oh, miserable and twice miserable, indeed greedy merchants! Farewell. Basel, April 18, 1547. Yours, Gastius.
To the well-learned Master Heinrich Bullinger, parish priest in Zurich, my dear, kind lord, to his hands. Zurich.
